Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Dynamic Spectrum Access for Mission Critical Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Public safety first responders have a need for increased access to radio spectrum to improve interoperability between agencies in natural and human-caused emergencies, and to accommodate bandwidth intensive applications such as mission critical video surveillance. Dynamic Spectrum Access, a new paradigm that promises improved RF spectrum access and efficiency, has been hindered in its application to mission critical networks by a lack of the detailed understanding of the spectrum utilization characteristics necessary to drive system development. This project is generating the fundamental long-term and high-resolution spectrum measurements needed to characterize the time, frequency, energy, and spatial dynamics of mission critical wireless networks in a dense urban environment (Chicago). Empirical and analytical models that characterize public safety spectrum utilization are being created from these measurements. The empirical and analytical models are being used in turn as inputs to discrete-event simulations of candidate mission critical Dynamic Spectrum Access approaches in order to assess the ability of these approaches to improve capacity, while maintaining the necessary performance as measured by access delay and interference tolerance. Results in the form of the RF measurements, empirical and analytical models of mission critical spectral utilization, and system models are being disseminated via a secure download server linked to the Illinois Institute of Technology website. This research will impact Public Safety stakeholders including government agencies, public safety standards bodies, the Federal Communications Commission, and equipment providers by assessing the feasibility of applying to mission critical public safety wireless networks and facilitating system development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Public safety first responders have a critical need for increased access to radio spectrum to improve interoperability between agencies especially in natural and human generated emergencies (e.g. Katrina and the World Trade Center attacks).  This is particularly true for the growing use of bandwidth intensive applications such as mission critical video surveillance of crime or command post observations of disaster scenes. The use of dynamic spectrum sharing technologies to improved RF spectrum access and efficiency has been hindered in its application to mission critical networks by a lack of the detailed understanding of the spectrum utilization characteristics necessary to drive system development.  This Illinois Institute of Technology - WiNCom project generated an extensive dataset containing the fundamental long-term and high-resolution spectrum measurements that are needed to characterize the time, frequency, energy, and spatial dynamics of mission critical wireless networks in a dense urban environment (in our case focused on Chicago). Interesting examples of this collected data include the spectrum usage data for the police vs. all land mobile radio ("walkie-talkie") users during the week before, during and the week after the "Great Chicago Blizzard of 2011" (Figure 1) and the time series view of the spectrum usage in the days before, during and after the Chicago NATO Summit meeting in May 2012 (Figure 2).

Predictive empirical and analytical models characterizing public safety spectrum utilization were created using these measurements both to train and subsequently to validate the models.  Once in place, the empirical and analytical models were used as inputs to discrete-event simulations of candidate mission critical dynamic spectrum access approaches in order to assess the ability of these approaches to improve spectrum utilization.  The improved utilization approaches were in turn tested to insure that the incumbent performance, as measured by access delay and interference tolerance, wasn't negatively impacted by the spectrum sharing approach. These research results in the form of the RF measurements, predictive empirical and analytical models of mission critical spectral utilization, and system models were and continue to be selectively disseminated via a web-based server housed at Illinois Institute of Technology.

The research effort has enhanced our spectrum observation capabilities at WiNCom and our abilities to handle the large volumes of data associated with these long term measurement efforts. This growth in capability is directly translated into an enhancement of the skill set of the graduate and undergraduate research assistants who have been working on the program. As these students continue to graduate, they take with them the knowledge and skills to support work in this area in the various companies and institutions that employ them. 

The research results are having a direct impact on various Public Safety stakeholders including federal, state and local government agencies, public safety standards bodies, the Federal Communications Commission, the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, and various public safety equipment providers.  This assessment of the feasibility of applying dynamic spectrum sharing techniques to mission critical public safety wireless networks and the resulting opportunity to facilitating public safety system development should have a broad impact on this important area of wireless communications both now and in the coming years.
